title: 109_s2762
content: The "Veterans Long-Term Care Security Act of 2006" requires a report to Congress before implementing any reduction in per diem rates for care provided to veterans in state homes. The "Veterans Long-Term Care Security Act of 2006" mandates that the Secretary must submit a detailed report to Congress by January 1 of the preceding fiscal year if proposing a reduction in payments under section 1741 of title 38, United States Code. This report must justify the proposed reduction, which includes a lack of increase in payment rates or a modification of veterans' eligibility. The Secretary must submit a detailed report to Congress if proposing a reduction in payments under section 1741 of title 38, United States Code. The report must justify the proposed reduction, which includes a lack of increase in payment rates or a modification of veterans' eligibility. The report should include consultation with State and local agencies responsible for State homes and organizations with expertise in State home matters. It should also describe the financial impact on each State home. The Secretary must submit a detailed report to Congress justifying any proposed reduction in payments under section 1741 of title 38, United States Code. This includes consultation with State and local agencies, as well as organizations with expertise in State home matters. The report must also address the financial impact on each State home, the intent to recover grant amounts, and the effect on veterans' long-term care needs. Section 4 grants authority to treat certain health facilities as state homes, effective October 1, 2006. Section 4 grants authority to treat health facilities as State homes if they meet specific requirements, including standards for nursing home care and licensing by State and local agencies. The State can apply to have a health facility treated as a State home if a substantial number of veterans in the area would not have access to nursing home care otherwise. The Secretary must approve the application if it best meets the needs of veterans in that area. The Secretary cannot approve the treatment if it would result in an excess of allocated beds for the State. The State can apply to have a health facility treated as a State home if a substantial number of veterans in the area would not have access to nursing home care otherwise. The number of beds allocated to the State cannot exceed the limit set by regulations, and the number of beds occupied by veterans in a health facility must not exceed the number permitted in State homes under regulations. The number of beds in a health facility treated as a State home will be considered in determining the unmet need for beds for State homes in the State. Treatment of certain health facilities as State homes allows the State to designate a health facility as a State home if a substantial number of veterans in the area would not have access to nursing home care otherwise. The number of beds allocated to the State must comply with regulations, and the occupancy of beds by veterans in the facility must also adhere to regulations. The beds in such designated health facilities will be considered in assessing the unmet need for State homes in the State.
